title: Stakeholder Adoption and Interoperability
statement: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.
acceptance_criteria: The system must be designed to be compatible with the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE) architecture.
The system must support interoperability with the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS).
The system's design must be adaptable to meet the digital health requirements of country governments, with Bangladesh as a reference example.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.

title: Stakeholder System Interoperability
statement: The system must be designed to be compatible with and usable by key stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and country-level government systems, such as that of Bangladesh.
acceptance_criteria: The system successfully demonstrates data exchange with an OpenHIE-compliant test environment.
The system successfully demonstrates integration and data exchange with an openIMIS test instance.
Documentation is provided confirming alignment with the specified requirements of the Bangladesh government's health information system.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.

title: Update National Health Insurance System Requirements
statement: The 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' must be used as the basis for updating the content of the 2012 requirements document.
acceptance_criteria: The 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is formally reviewed and accepted as the source for updates.
A gap analysis between the 2012 document and the new guide is completed and documented.
A new version of the system requirements document, incorporating updates from the guide, is drafted and approved by stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Update to National Health Insurance Information Systems Guide
statement: The system must be updated to comply with the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems', which is the result of the Determining workshop and serves as the update to the 2012 document.
acceptance_criteria: The updated 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is obtained and reviewed.
A compliance matrix is created, mapping system features to the requirements outlined in the guide.
A gap analysis is performed and a report is generated, identifying any discrepancies between the current system and the new requirements.
Evidence of compliance for each requirement in the guide is documented and verified.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Living Document Contribution Process
statement: A process shall be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for submitting contributions for requirement updates is created and published.
A designated channel (e.g., web portal, email alias, code repository) for receiving community contributions is established.
A review, approval, and integration workflow for submitted contributions is defined and assigned to a responsible role.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.

title: Support for National Health Insurance Systems
statement: The system must be designed to support a national health insurance framework, operationalizing health financing transactions for paying for and delivering health services, to facilitate a country's progress toward Universal Health Coverage (UHC) for its citizens.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall be capable of processing end-to-end health financing transactions, including service delivery verification, claim submission, adjudication, and payment settlement.
System documentation must explicitly map its core functions to the operational requirements of the national health insurance scheme and its Universal Health Coverage goals.
The system must provide reporting dashboards for key performance indicators (KPIs) related to health service delivery and financing, as specified by national health authorities.

metadata.raw_input: A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: Ongoing Updates for Living Resource
statement: A process must be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure system requirements continue to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for submitting, reviewing, and incorporating updates to the requirements is established and accessible.
The process defines roles and responsibilities for the update cycle.
The requirements document is reviewed at a predefined frequency (e.g., annually).

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource. A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: National Scale Health Information Systems
statement: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture and design must be documented to support implementation at a national scale.
The system must demonstrate compliance with relevant national healthcare regulations (e.g., HIPAA in the US).
Stress and performance testing results must validate the system's capacity to handle projected national-level transaction volumes.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.

title: Insurance Information System Efficacy and Integrity
statement: The health insurance information system must be designed to ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, identify system efficiencies, prevent fraudulent activities, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment for all members.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E)
acceptance_criteria: Reimbursement processing time for 95% of clean claims must be within 15 business days, as defined by the Service Level Agreement (SLA).
The system must include a reporting module that identifies bottlenecks in the claims processing workflow, such as stages with the longest processing times.
The system must implement an automated fraud detection engine that flags suspicious claims based on predefined rules and machine learning models.

System audits must demonstrate no statistically significant disparities in claim approval rates or reimbursement amounts based on protected characteristics as defined by compliance standards (e.g., ACA Section 1557).
The average cost per electronic transaction must show a measurable decrease against a pre-defined baseline within 6 months of go-live.

metadata.raw_input: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Information System Core Capabilities
statement: The health insurance information system must support national-scale operations by providing functionalities to ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, identify system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment for all members.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C
HIPAA - Privacy Rule - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E
acceptance_criteria: The system can process 99% of standard reimbursement claims within 5 business days.
The system demonstrates a measurable reduction in per-transaction processing cost compared to a defined baseline.
The system includes reporting and analytics modules to identify key areas for operational efficiency improvements.
The system's fraud detection module correctly identifies and flags known fraudulent claim patterns with a true positive rate of over 95%.
System audit logs and reports demonstrate that coverage and treatment rules are applied consistently across all member profiles, with no detectable bias.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale. Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of integrating and utilizing health insurance data to complement other types of health system data, in accordance with national and international regulations.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully connect to and ingest data from a specified health insurance data source.
Health insurance data is correctly associated with the corresponding patient records within the system.
Access to the integrated health insurance data is restricted based on user roles and permissions.
All handling of health insurance data (storage, transmission, display) must be logged and auditable to ensure compliance.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of ingesting and integrating health insurance data to complement other types of health system data, such as clinical or demographic data.
regulation: HIPAA (Privacy Rule, 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E)
HIPAA (Security Rule, 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a secure mechanism (e.g., API, SFTP) to import health insurance data.
Imported health insurance data can be successfully parsed and stored in a secure, encrypted manner.
The system can link imported insurance data to the correct patient records within the existing health system.
Authorized users can view a consolidated record that displays both clinical data and complementary insurance data for a patient.
All access to and import of health insurance data is logged in an immutable audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Use of Functional Requirements in Development
statement: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for defining, reviewing, and approving functional requirements is documented and followed.
Functional requirements are captured and maintained in a designated requirements management system.
Evidence of review and utilization by designated actors (policymakers, systems engineers, technical experts) is recorded for all functional requirements throughout the system development lifecycle.

metadata.raw_input: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.

title: Machine-Readable Export of National Priorities
statement: The system shall provide a function for technical experts to access and export national healthcare priorities in a structured, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON, XML) that is transferable and suitable for software design and implementation.
acceptance_criteria: A user with the 'System Expert' role can access a dedicated interface for viewing national priorities.
The system provides an option to export the national priorities data.
The exported file must be in a valid, well-formed JSON or XML format.
The schema of the exported data must be documented and the export must conform to it.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation.

title: Cross-functional Requirement Specification Format
statement: These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.
acceptance_criteria: A standardized requirement template is created and approved by both technical and non-technical stakeholders.
A sample requirement written in the new format is reviewed by a health insurance expert and a software engineer, and both confirm they can understand the system behavior described without ambiguity.
The format explicitly supports the inclusion of information for prioritization, behavioral specification, and system design considerations.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Cross-functional Requirement Specification Format
statement: System requirements must be specified in a format that is understandable to both domain experts (e.g., health insurance experts) and software engineers. This format must be transferable to software design and implementation, and serve as a common platform for behavior specification, prioritization, compromise, and system design.
acceptance_criteria: A requirement specification template is formally defined and documented.
The template is successfully used to capture a sample requirement.
The sample requirement is reviewed and confirmed to be clear and unambiguous by representatives from both business (e.g., health insurance) and technical (e.g., software engineering) teams.
The approved template is mandated for use in all project requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation. These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Jurisdictional Configurability
statement: The system must be configurable to accommodate specific regulatory, legal, and organizational requirements defined by the country or organization in which it is deployed.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can define and apply a set of compliance rules specific to a designated country or organization.
System behavior (e.g., data retention policies, consent requirements, audit logging) must adapt and be enforced according to the applied jurisdictional rule set.
Configuration for one jurisdiction must not interfere with the configuration of another within a multi-tenant or multi-region deployment.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs.

title: Leverage Common Requirements for Development
statement: A set of globally defined common requirements shall be used as a starting point for development to ensure adherence to best practices and to optimize time and resources.
acceptance_criteria: A documented set of common requirements is established and maintained.
Evidence demonstrates that development projects reference and utilize the common requirements set as a baseline.
Project documentation shows traceability from specific features back to the common requirements where applicable.

metadata.raw_input: The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Leverage Global Requirements as a Baseline
statement: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence that a review of relevant global standards and best practices was conducted during the requirements gathering phase.
The project's requirements specification document references applicable global standards as a basis for derived requirements.
A justification is documented for any deviation from reviewed global best practices.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Common Requirement Definition Process
statement: A standardized process shall be implemented for defining, reviewing, and managing common requirements to ensure they are consistent, reusable, and serve as a reliable foundation for system development and verification.
acceptance_criteria: A documented procedure for the common requirement lifecycle (creation, review, approval, update) is approved and available.
A standardized template for writing common requirements is created and in use.
Roles and responsibilities for the process are clearly defined in the procedure.
Training on the new process has been provided to all relevant actors.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge.

title: Support for Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system must be architected to support a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, accommodating differences in their design, coverage levels, and maturity. This includes the ability to configure and adapt to different functional, data, and regulatory requirements associated with each scheme.
acceptance_criteria: System can be configured to support at least two distinct national health coverage models (e.g., a US-based private insurance model and a UK-based NHS model).
Configuration for a new health scheme can be performed by an administrator through a dedicated interface without requiring new code deployment.
Rules for patient eligibility, service coverage, and billing logic must be adjustable based on the selected country scheme.

metadata.raw_input: Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: Support for Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system must be designed to be configurable for a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, which differ in design, coverage, and maturity. The architecture must be flexible enough to accommodate different functional and regulatory requirements based on the target country's healthcare model.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must support the definition and implementation of country-specific business rules and workflows through a configuration interface or files, without requiring a new code deployment.
The system can be successfully configured to model at least two distinct, real-world country health schemes (e.g., a single-payer system vs. a multi-payer private insurance system).
Documentation is available for administrators detailing the process for configuring the system for a new country's health scheme.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge. Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: CRDM Applicability Scope
statement: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.
acceptance_criteria: The project's system development lifecycle (SDLC) documentation explicitly states the use of the CRDM methodology.
Requirements documents are structured according to CRDM principles.
The chosen methodology is justified by referencing its successful application in related domains like health insurance, logistics, or maternal health systems.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text, labels, and messages are written at or below an 8th-grade reading level, as measured by a standard readability index (e.g., Flesch-Kincaid).
Usability testing with a panel of representative users (clinicians, patients) confirms that system terminology is clear and understandable with a success rate of >95% on comprehension tasks.
A glossary of terms used in the system is reviewed and approved by a panel of subject matter experts and target users.

metadata.raw_input: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Use of Nontechnical Language
statement: All system interfaces, documentation, and user-facing communications must use nontechnical language that is familiar to the intended users and subject matter experts to ensure clarity, reduce ambiguity, and enhance ease of use.
acceptance_criteria: A glossary of approved, user-friendly terms is established and followed throughout the system.
Usability testing with representative users confirms that system terminology is clear and understandable with a satisfaction score of at least 90%.
A review of all user-facing text by a panel of subject matter experts confirms the absence of technical jargon.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more. A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Beneficiary Management Capability
statement: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for authorized users to manage beneficiary records.
The system must support creating, viewing, updating, and deactivating/archiving beneficiary profiles.
The system must be able to handle beneficiary data regardless of whether a formal enrollment process is required for a specific scheme.
Access to beneficiary management functions must be restricted to authorized roles (e.g., admin).

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Support for Global Data Exchange Standards
statement: The system shall utilize HL7 FHIR and other relevant global standards for data exchange to ensure interoperability and alignment of business processes with other digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully send a patient summary document using a specified HL7 FHIR profile to a compliant third-party system.
The system can successfully receive and correctly parse an incoming HL7 FHIR resource (e.g., Observation for lab results, MedicationRequest for prescriptions).
Data mapping between the system's internal data model and the HL7 FHIR standard is documented and verified for key data types.
The system successfully passes relevant tests on a standard interoperability test platform (e.g., Inferno, Aegis Touchstone).

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Data Exchange Standards Compliance
statement: The system shall utilize HL7 FHIR and other global standards for data exchange to align business processes across digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully send and receive patient data using HL7 FHIR compliant APIs.
Data exchange endpoints are validated against a standard FHIR validator.
Key business processes, such as patient admission or lab ordering, are mapped to corresponding FHIR resources and workflows.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall allow for the creation, viewing, updating, and deletion of task sets. A task set is defined as a collection of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.
regulation: FDA - 21 CFR Part 820 - Quality System Regulation
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user (Admin) can create a new task set with a unique name and description.
The user can add one or more predefined tasks to the task set.
The user can reorder the steps within a task set.
The system displays a list of all existing task sets.
An authorized user can select and modify an existing task set (e.g., change its name, add/remove tasks).
An authorized user can delete a task set, provided it is not currently associated with any active business processes.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall support the concept of a Task set, defined as the set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can create a new task set containing a sequence of steps.
Each step within the task set can be defined with a specific activity or instruction.
The system saves the defined task set and it can be associated with one or more business processes.
A user, such as a clinician, can view the steps of a task set assigned to them.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Scheme Process Selection
statement: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is configuring their country's scheme.
When the administrator views the available process options.
Then the system must display a clear comparison outlining the differences between each option.
And the administrator must be able to select and save a process for their scheme.
And the system must confirm that the selected process has been applied.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Scheme Process Options Display
statement: The system shall outline the differences between available processes, enabling users to understand the breadth of options and select the most relevant ones for their specific scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is on the scheme configuration page,
When the administrator views the process options,
Then the system must display a clear comparison of all available processes.
And the comparison must detail the key differences, benefits, and implications of each option.
And the administrator must be able to select and save a process configuration for their scheme.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Business Process Visualization
statement: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.
regulation: GDPR - Article 30 - Records of processing activities
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a graphical tool to model a business process.
The graphical representation must clearly identify the actors/roles involved in the process.
The representation must show the flow of information and data between actors.
The representation must depict the sequence of tasks and decision points.
A user can export or print the graphical representation for review and documentation.

metadata.raw_input: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must facilitate a process where a beneficiary presents proof of their insurer identification. The process must ensure the captured insurance information is accurate and verified against the presented proof.
acceptance_criteria: Given a beneficiary is being registered, the system must prompt the user to request and capture the beneficiary's insurer identification.
The system must provide a mechanism to upload or scan a copy of the beneficiary's insurance card as proof.
The system must validate that key insurance fields (e.g., Member ID, Group ID, Payer Name) are populated.
The process is successfully completed when the user confirms that the presented identification has been verified against the entered data.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Identity and Insurer Verification
statement: The system must support a process for staff to verify a beneficiary's identity and their insurer information. The process requires the beneficiary to present valid proof of identity and insurance, which must be captured and validated for accuracy and completeness as per regulatory and payer requirements.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for a user to capture beneficiary identification information (e.g., via manual entry or scanning an ID card).
The system must provide an interface for a user to capture the beneficiary's insurance information (e.g., via manual entry or scanning an insurance card).
The system must include a mechanism to flag the beneficiary's record as 'Identity Verified' and 'Insurance Verified' upon successful validation by staff.
The system must be capable of performing real-time insurance eligibility checks (e.g., via an X12 270/271 transaction).
All captured identification and insurance data must be stored securely and encrypted in compliance with the HIPAA Security Rule.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Document Validation
statement: The system shall enable an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and ensure all required data fields are complete for benefits qualification.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
GDPR (Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data)
acceptance_criteria: An authenticated user with the 'Insurer' role can access the beneficiary's credential review interface.
The interface must display all captured identification information, including name, address, and any other qualifying data like biometrics.
The system must present all submitted documents for the Insurer to review for validity.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to approve or reject the submitted credentials and documents.
The system must validate that all mandatory fields are complete before allowing the Insurer to approve the beneficiary's profile.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and ensure all required data fields are complete. The system must also correctly identify and present all benefit plans for which the beneficiary qualifies.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must flag any incomplete or missing required fields in the beneficiary's data.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the beneficiary's credentials as 'verified' or 'rejected'.
Upon successful verification, the system must display a complete list of all benefit plans the beneficiary is eligible for.
All access to and actions performed on the beneficiary's data must be logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting
statement: All requirement statements must begin with the phrase 'The system must' to ensure clarity, consistency, and testability across all project documentation.
acceptance_criteria: An audit of the requirements specification document confirms that all requirement statements start with the phrase 'The system must'.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All system requirements must be phrased to describe what the system shall accomplish, avoiding any specific reference to implementation technologies or solutions. Each requirement statement should clearly articulate the necessary outcome or capability.
acceptance_criteria: Each functional requirement statement begins with a standard phrase like 'The system shall...'.

Requirement statements describe a verifiable capability or outcome, not a technical implementation (e.g., 'The system shall store patient records' is acceptable; 'The system shall use a PostgreSQL database' is not).

A formal review of the requirements specification document confirms the absence of specific programming languages, databases, or proprietary components unless they are explicitly defined as a system constraint.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting
statement: Statements usually begin with “The system must . .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.
acceptance_criteria: All system requirements in the specification document begin with 'The system shall' or 'The system must'.
A review of the requirements specification confirms that requirements describe outcomes and not implementation details.
Requirements are verifiable and do not contain references to specific software libraries, hardware, or proprietary technologies unless part of a constraint.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must . .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Role-Based Access Control for Patient Data
statement: The system must implement role-based access controls to ensure that users can only access, view, or modify patient data according to their assigned clinical or administrative roles.
acceptance_criteria: GIVEN a user with a 'clinician' role, WHEN they log in, THEN they can access patient records assigned to them.
GIVEN a user with an 'admin' role, WHEN they access the user management module, THEN they can assign or revoke user roles.
GIVEN a user with a 'patient' role, WHEN they log in, THEN they can only view their own health information and cannot access other patient records.
GIVEN a user without 'clinician' privileges, WHEN they attempt to access a clinical record, THEN the system must deny access and log the attempt.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: System Support for Process Activities
statement: The system must provide a framework to define, execute, and track clinical and administrative process activities. Each activity must be clearly defined with its steps, inputs, outputs, associated user roles, and required actions.
acceptance_criteria: Verify that an administrator can define a new process activity via the UI, specifying its steps, required data, and assigned roles.
Verify that a user with an assigned role (e.g., 'Clinician') can view and initiate a relevant process activity.
Verify that the system enforces the defined workflow, preventing unauthorized actions or step-skipping.
Verify that all actions performed within a process activity are logged in an immutable audit trail, capturing the user, timestamp, and action details.
Verify that the status of each process activity instance (e.g., 'in progress', 'completed') is tracked and viewable by authorized personnel.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Incorporate Country-Specific Requirements
statement: The global set of system requirements must be updated and expanded based on applicable country-specific requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for identifying, reviewing, and incorporating country-specific requirements into the global requirements set.
For each target market/country, there is auditable evidence demonstrating the comparison of local requirements against the global set.
New or updated global requirements are created and are traceable back to the source country-specific requirement that prompted the change.

metadata.raw_input: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.

title: Incorporate Country-Specific Requirements
statement: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for identifying and reviewing country-specific requirements on a regular basis.
When a new or updated country-specific requirement is identified, it is formally evaluated against the existing global requirements set.
The global requirements set is updated or expanded to incorporate the country-specific requirement if a gap is identified.
All changes to the global requirements set are version-controlled and traceable to the source country-specific regulation.

metadata.raw_input: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.

title: Contextual Requirement Analysis
statement: A review of common requirements shall be conducted to address what specific requirements are relevant for the context, given applicable national policies and the overall scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A document is produced that lists the applicable national policies and regulations.
A document is produced detailing the scheme design and its implications on system requirements.
A final set of context-relevant requirements is formally documented and approved, with traceability to the source policies and design.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Review of Requirements for Policy Alignment
statement: A review of common requirements must be conducted to identify and incorporate all relevant requirements based on the specific context, including national policies and scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A formal review process for identifying applicable national policies and scheme design constraints is documented.
A traceability matrix is created that maps identified policies and scheme designs to specific system requirements.
The list of applicable policies and regulations is approved by the Compliance Officer.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Define Functional Scope
statement: The system shall provide a mechanism for the team to define and document the functional scope of a project or initiative.
acceptance_criteria: Verify that an authorized user can access a dedicated interface for defining functional scope.
Verify that the user can input, format, and save the scope definition.
Verify that the saved scope definition can be retrieved for viewing and editing by authorized users.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope).

title: Secure Team Question & Communication Feature
statement: The system shall provide a secure feature for authorized team members to ask essential questions related to patient data, care coordination, or clinical workflows.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.312(e)(1) Transmission Security
HIPAA Privacy Rule - 45 CFR § 164.502 Uses and Disclosures of PHI
acceptance_criteria: Given an authenticated clinician, when they are viewing a patient's chart, then they must have an option to 'Ask a Question'.
Given a user has composed a question, when they send it, the communication must be encrypted in transit (e.g., TLS 1.2+) and at rest.
Given a question has been sent, then an immutable audit log is created, capturing the sender, recipient(s), timestamp, and patient context.
Given a user who is not part of the patient's care team, when they attempt to view or ask questions about that patient, then the system must deny access.

metadata.raw_input: It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Functional Scope Definition
statement: The system shall provide a mechanism for the project team to define the functional scope and to document essential questions related to the requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A designated user can create, edit, and save a new functional requirement document or entry within the system.
The system allows for the association of questions, comments, or clarifications with each requirement entry.
The defined scope and questions are version-controlled and auditable.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope). It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Country-Specific Regulatory Analysis
statement: The system must be analyzed to identify and document all relevant requirements based on the specific national laws and healthcare scheme rules of the target country of deployment.
regulation: To be determined based on country context (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR, FDA, National Health Acts, local data privacy laws)
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive document is produced detailing all applicable national and scheme-specific rules for the target country.
A gap analysis report is created, comparing current system capabilities against the identified rules.
A set of new, country-specific requirements is created to ensure full compliance.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules?

title: Define Provider and Payer System Requirements
statement: The system shall have clearly defined, documented, and agreed-upon functional and non-functional requirements for both the provider-facing and payer-facing components.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive requirements specification document is created and maintained.
The document clearly delineates requirements specific to the provider side of the platform.
The document clearly delineates requirements specific to the payer side of the platform.
Each requirement is uniquely identifiable, testable, and traceable.
The requirements specification document is formally reviewed and approved by key stakeholders (e.g., Product, Engineering, QA, Compliance).

metadata.raw_input: • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Country-Specific Compliance Analysis
statement: The system must identify, document, and incorporate all relevant healthcare requirements specific to the country's national and scheme rules. This includes defining distinct requirements for both provider and payer stakeholders.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive list of all applicable national and scheme rules is compiled and documented.
A set of specific, testable requirements derived from these rules is created.
Requirements are clearly segregated for provider-side and payer-side implementation.
The documented requirements are reviewed and approved by legal and compliance stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules? • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: HIS Integration and Interoperability
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS). If direct integration is not supported, an interface must be designed, built, and implemented to ensure seamless data exchange.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - Technical Safeguards (45 CFR 164.312)
acceptance_criteria: The solution demonstrates successful, bi-directional data exchange with a designated test HIS environment using standard protocols (e.g., HL7, FHIR).
Data integrity is maintained during transmission, with a 0% data loss or corruption rate.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2 or higher.
The integration response time for critical data queries does not exceed the specified performance benchmark (e.g., <2 seconds).
Complete documentation for the interface design and API specifications is provided and approved by the hospital's IT governance board.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it?

title: Requirement Prioritization
statement: A process must be in place to classify requirements as either essential (must-have) for core functionality, safety, or compliance, or non-essential (nice-to-have).
acceptance_criteria: A documented methodology for prioritizing requirements is established and approved.
All requirements in the backlog or specification document are assigned a priority level (e.g., 'essential', 'non-essential').
The rationale for priority assignment is documented, especially for requirements deemed essential due to risk, safety, or regulatory impact.

metadata.raw_input: • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: HIS Integration and Interoperability
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS), such as Electronic Health Records (EHR), Laboratory Information Systems (LIS), and Picture Archiving and Communication Systems (PACS). The specific integration methods (e.g., HL7, FHIR, custom APIs) and data flows must be defined and implemented based on the target hospital's infrastructure.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully establish a connection to a target HIS/EHR using a standard protocol (e.g., HL7, FHIR).
Patient data (e.g., demographics, lab results) can be successfully queried and retrieved from the HIS into the solution.
Data generated within the solution can be successfully transmitted and correctly filed in the patient's record in the HIS.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it? • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: Managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
acceptance_criteria: A formal evaluation process must be defined and documented.
A comparison matrix or scorecard must be created, comparing at least two solution alternatives against predefined organizational needs (e.g., functional, technical, compliance, financial).
The final selection must be justified in a report, referencing the evaluation matrix and demonstrating how the chosen system best meets the documented needs.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: A process must be in place for managers to evaluate multiple solution alternatives and select the system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: A formal evaluation process for selecting new systems is documented and approved.
A comparison matrix is utilized to score at least two solution alternatives against predefined organizational needs, including clinical, technical, and compliance requirements.
The final selection is justified with a report referencing the comparison matrix, demonstrating the best fit for the organization.
Sign-off on the final selection is obtained from key stakeholders, including representatives from clinical, administrative, and IT departments.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Software Evaluation and Trade-off Principle
statement: The software selection process must acknowledge that different software packages will exhibit varying levels of strength across the full spectrum of functional, security, and performance requirements. A risk-based approach shall be used to evaluate and accept trade-offs.
regulation: ISO - 14971 (Application of risk management to medical devices)
acceptance_criteria: A documented trade-off analysis or scoring matrix is produced for all evaluated software packages.
The final selection decision is justified with a risk assessment report, highlighting accepted risks and mitigation strategies.
Stakeholder input from different roles (e.g., clinical, technical, compliance) is documented in the evaluation records.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Comparative Software Evaluation
statement: A process must be in place to evaluate and compare software packages, acknowledging that no single package may excel in all specified requirements. This process must support trade-off analysis to select the most suitable solution based on a weighted prioritization of all requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented software evaluation and selection procedure exists.
The procedure includes a method for weighting or prioritizing requirements for trade-off analysis.
Evaluation reports demonstrate a comparative analysis of software candidates against the prioritized requirements.
The final selection rationale is documented, justifying any trade-offs made.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Development Process for Functionality Definition
statement: Software developers must be able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence exists that software development activities are traced to established business processes and requirements documents.
Code commits and feature documentation reference the specific business requirements they are intended to fulfill.
A Quality Management System (QMS) document defining the business development process is available and referenced by the development team.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements.

title: Implementation Flexibility
statement: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: For any given functional requirement, the chosen software solution is demonstrably verified against the specified inputs, outputs, and outcomes.
Development teams can provide a clear rationale for their chosen implementation, linking it to the requirement's objectives.

Architectural and implementation choices are not arbitrarily constrained, allowing for optimal solutions unless specific constraints (e.g., security, performance) are explicitly defined in other requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Developer Implementation Flexibility
statement: Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Traceability matrix demonstrates a clear link from business requirements to the implemented software solution.
Design documentation justifies the chosen software solution and architecture against the business objectives.
Code reviews and testing verify that the implemented solution's inputs, outputs, and outcomes align with the source business requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Common Requirements Document as Design Baseline
statement: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A common requirements document exists and is maintained under version control.
The document serves as the acknowledged baseline for all new software design and development initiatives.
A formal process is established for proposing, reviewing, and approving customizations for specific countries or systems against the common requirements baseline.
Traceability is established between the common requirements document and software design specifications.

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: CRDM Process for Business Process and Requirement Documentation
statement: The CRDM (Collaborative Requirements Development Methodology) process must be used to systematically identify, discuss, agree upon, and document all business processes and their related project-specific requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented CRDM process guide is available and approved for project use.
All project business processes and requirements are documented following the CRDM process.
Evidence of collaborative sessions for requirement identification and agreement is available (e.g., meeting minutes, workshop outputs).
All documented requirements are signed-off by relevant stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically.

title: Local Requirement Analysis and Consensus
statement: Generic key process requirements must undergo a formal analysis and consensus-building exercise at the country or project level to ensure local applicability and value.
acceptance_criteria: A formal analysis and consensus-building exercise is conducted for each country or project implementation.
A localized requirements specification document is produced as an output of the exercise.
The localized document, including any deviations or additions from the generic requirements, is formally approved and signed off by designated country/project stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Use CRDM Process for Requirement Definition
statement: The CRDM (Consensus-based Requirements Definition Methodology) process shall be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document business processes and their related project-specific requirements. While some generic requirements may be pre-mapped, the analysis and consensus-building aspects of the CRDM process must be applied at the country or project level to ensure specific needs are met.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of CRDM workshops being conducted for project-specific requirements is available.
A requirements specification document is produced as a formal output of the CRDM process.
Sign-off on the requirements specification document is obtained from all relevant project stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically. Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Material and Requirement Alignment Verification
statement: The system must provide a mechanism to cross-check operational materials (e.g., Standard Operating Procedures, training guides) against system requirements to ensure they are aligned and that all processes are comprehensively covered by both.
acceptance_criteria: Given a user with appropriate permissions, they can access both the requirements list and the repository of operational materials.
The system must provide a feature to link one or more material documents to a specific requirement ID.
A traceability report can be generated that displays all requirements and their linked materials, highlighting any requirements that have no material linkage.
The traceability report must also be able to show all materials and their linked requirements, highlighting any materials not linked to a requirement.

metadata.raw_input: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.

title: Requirement and Material Alignment Verification
statement: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.
acceptance_criteria: A traceability matrix or equivalent mechanism must exist to link each requirement to its corresponding design, development, and testing materials.
Authorized users must be able to generate a report or view demonstrating the coverage of all requirements by the associated materials.
The system or process must be able to identify and flag any requirements that lack corresponding materials or have identified misalignments.
An audit trail must be maintained for all cross-checking and verification activities.

metadata.raw_input: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.

title: Improve Data Quality
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to improve data quality, addressing common issues such as inaccuracies, incompleteness, and inconsistencies in patient and clinical data to ensure data integrity and reliability.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall validate data upon entry against predefined formats and rules (e.g., date of birth format, valid medication codes).
The system must provide a mechanism for authorized users to identify and merge duplicate patient records.
A data quality dashboard shall be available to administrators, reporting on key metrics such as data completeness and accuracy rates for critical fields.
The system must flag or prevent the entry of clinically implausible data (e.g., out-of-range lab values, invalid dosages) for user review.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common.

title: Data Flow and Process Analysis
statement: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.
regulation: GDPR - Article 30 - Records of processing activities
FDA - Cybersecurity in Medical Devices Guidance
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive data flow diagram (DFD) is created, documenting all data ingress, processing, storage, and egress points.
A data inventory document is produced that maps all system data types to their lifecycle stages.
The analysis explicitly identifies all internal and external systems that data is received from or shared with.
The analysis identifies all user roles and their interactions with data throughout the system.
The resulting documentation (DFD, data inventory) is reviewed and approved by the designated Compliance and Security officers.

metadata.raw_input: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Data Quality and Integrity Analysis
statement: The system must support the analysis of business processes to improve data quality. This includes capabilities to determine where data enters the system (either directly collected or from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems to identify and mitigate data quality issues.
acceptance_criteria: A data flow diagram can be generated or documented, mapping all data ingress, processing, and egress points.
The system provides tools or logs to audit the data lifecycle for a given record, including creation, modification, and access.
A data quality dashboard or reporting mechanism exists to identify common data anomalies (e.g., missing fields, incorrect formats, outliers).
A data governance plan is documented, outlining procedures for data validation, error correction, and regular auditing, and the system supports these procedures.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common. An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Process Management
statement: The system shall provide authorized stakeholders with the necessary reporting and data analysis tools to effectively identify, monitor, and resolve issues within specific business processes by providing access to relevant data.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized stakeholder (e.g., Business Analyst), when they navigate to the reporting module, they can select a specific business process (e.g., Patient Intake).
The system must display a dashboard with relevant KPIs and metrics for the selected business process.
The user must be able to filter the data by date range and other relevant parameters (e.g., location, department) to investigate specific issues.
The system must provide a feature to export the filtered data or report in a standard format (e.g., CSV, PDF).
All access to data containing PHI for reporting purposes must be recorded in the system's audit log, detailing the user, timestamp, and data accessed.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Processes
statement: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.
acceptance_criteria: Verify that an authorized stakeholder can access a dashboard or reporting interface tailored to their business process needs.
Verify that the interface allows the stakeholder to view and analyze data relevant to pre-defined business issues.
Verify that role-based access control is implemented, ensuring stakeholders can only access the minimum necessary data required for their role.
Verify that a stakeholder can generate or export a report containing the data needed for their specific business process.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Resource Usability and Maintainability
statement: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).
acceptance_criteria: All user documentation and resources are available in a common, downloadable format (e.g., PDF).
Documentation sections must be individually referenceable via unique URLs or anchors.
Where applicable, resources are provided in an adaptable format (e.g., templates in DOCX) to allow for local customization.
A version history for all documentation is maintained and accessible.
The process for updating and maintaining documentation is defined and auditable.

metadata.raw_input: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).

title: System Scalability for National Health Schemes
statement: Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system must support a target number of concurrent users (e.g., 1,000,000) with an average response time of less than 2 seconds for all critical transactions.
The system must demonstrate horizontal scalability, allowing for increased capacity by adding more server nodes without requiring a system redesign.
Load testing must show that the system can process a peak volume of transactions (e.g., 10,000 claims per minute) while maintaining performance within acceptable thresholds.
The system's data storage must scale to accommodate a projected 5-year growth in patient and transactional data without performance degradation.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.

title: Feasibility of Common Functional Requirements for National Health Insurance Systems
statement: Investigate and determine the feasibility of establishing a set of common functional requirements for a national health insurance system, considering the historical observation that there has been little reuse of such systems from country to country.
acceptance_criteria: A feasibility study report is produced and delivered.
The report analyzes at least three existing national health insurance systems from different countries, highlighting similarities and differences.
The report identifies a proposed set of common functional requirements and a list of functions that require country-specific customization.
The findings and recommendations are reviewed and approved by the architecture review board and key project stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Scalable Information System for National Health Insurance
statement: The system must be an effective and scalable information platform to support the development and operation of national health insurance schemes. The system's design should be based on a set of common, reusable functional requirements to promote interoperability and successful adoption across different countries or regions.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must be documented and demonstrate the ability to scale to support a national-level user base.
A core set of common functional modules for health insurance (e.g., enrollment, claims processing, provider management) must be identified and implemented.
Performance benchmarks for scalability (e.g., transactions per second, concurrent users) must be defined and met during load testing.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems. At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: The system shall support common functional requirements that are shared across different countries, as identified through the application of the Clinical Research Data Model (CRDM).
acceptance_criteria: A list of common functional requirements shared across target countries is documented, based on the CRDM analysis.
The system architecture and design documents explicitly address how these common functional requirements are implemented.
System validation tests confirm that the core functionalities operate correctly according to the shared requirements across simulated regional configurations (e.g., US, EU).

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A core set of functional requirements is defined and documented as being applicable to all targeted countries.
System architecture and design documents reflect a modular approach, separating core functionality from country-specific localizations.
Traceability analysis confirms that core functional requirements are implemented consistently across different country deployments.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
